docs.lead_paragraph: IN the year before they had heart attacks, middle-aged men were found to worry, feel sad, anxious, fatigued, lacking in libido and yet were apparently unconcerned about the risk of having an incurable illness. British doctors used signs of this emotional climate to help predict which men, aged 40 to 65, were going to have heart attacks within a year. The study, reported in The Lancet, said the doctors scored better than 81 percent in using the emotional and related criteria to distinguish between men who would and would not have heart attacks. The researchers scored about 66 percent in identifying men whose attacks were imminent.
